data.text: Is the Mickelson Bike Trail from Deadwood to Edgemont any good?
The Mickelson bike trail from Deadwood SD to Edgemont SD? What are your thoughts about it? Have you ridden it? Worth it? Suggestions?

A group of buddies and I did last summer. Started Deadwood and made to Edgemont in one day. Stayed at the little hotel in Edgemont. Early rise, made it back to Deadwood before nightfall. There are some long climbs.
data.author: Sam Bertsch

data.text: thanks! How‚Äôs the views?

data.text: The northern section is more interesting and beautiful. The tunnels are great. If I was doing again, I'd stop at Custer or nearby. Edgemont is a small RR town that wasn't that interesting to me.

https://ridewithgps.com/trips/69905384. I had a full separate loop planned but I wasn't sure about finding water and food off the trail south of Custer so I did an out/back on that section of Mickelson trail.

data.text: It was a great time - we rode it as a family a couple of years ago. Plan to stay in lodging along the way - camping is near nonexistent. If you can, book a cabin at the place that‚Äôs also a little farm. It was awesome!
data.author: Adam Davidson

data.text: Goes over 7000‚Äô elevation No camping on trail
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: really?? No state forest land along or near the trail with remote, leave no trace camping off trail nearby?
data.author: Dev √òutd√≤√≥rs

data.text: there are campground spaces in every town along the way. During sturgis motorcycle rally they are all full.
data.author: Tom Cavan

data.text: illegal on this trail Check their website for details By now i am sure they know all the illegal camping sites and check them often
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: We rode with our kids and stayed at Carsten Cottages, Fun adventure! Peacocks coming into the cabin to say hello, Llamas lounging around, horses running in the pasture and Elk bugling at sunrise. The aggressive turkey Bojangles that chased us around at dinner time apparently met his maker üòÜ Great ride and there is heaps of NF and logging roads to explore t/o the hills for alternative routes and camping. The centennial trail is awesome and not all that technically challenging depending on the section and you bike/skill.

data.text: great

data.text: Great area. Mickelson is fantastic. Custer state park is a must visit as well. Just avoid the motorcycle rally crowds in late summer.

data.text: i parked in the big Deadwood trailhead lot. I spoke to a nice police officer and he noted my car and my planned return date. Made me feel safer about my car & MTB bike inside.

data.text: I haven‚Äôt ridden the trail, but my parents live about a mile off it. It‚Äôs absolutely gorgeous country.
data.author: Erik Jansen

data.text: There is a nice grassy campground in Hill City, right next to the trail. Not free however.
data.author: Curt Door

data.text: Fabulous ride I have ridden it twice. Deadwood to Edgemont is the preferred direction but be warned the first 19 miles from deadwood are uphill. Camped the first trip and used private campgrounds. Definitely take the time to visit Custer State Park, Wind Cave, Crazyhorse and Mount Rushmore. Plan on returning one day and riding Needles Highway!
data.author: Michele Hedrick

data.text: thank you, I thought about looping back and hitting some highlights as you suggested. Do you know how the shoulders are on the paved roads in Custer and needles hwy?
data.author: Dev √òutd√≤√≥rs

data.text: there is a bike path that takes you from Custer to Custer State Park. Needles Highway is narrow with no shoulder I would only ride it early in the morning.
data.author: Michele Hedrick

data.text: there is a 35 mile loop from Custer and through Needles and then takes you back to Custer but I have not ridden it.
data.author: Michele Hedrick

data.text: Thanks!!
